captions.text: l thought you were in London.

No, l came back a day early.
We would not have come...

had we known you were here.
Some business with my steward.

l'm in Derbyshire
with my aunt and uncle.

And are you having
a pleasant trip?

Tomorrow we go to Matlock.
Tomorrow?

Are you staying at Lambton?
Yes. At the Rose and Crown.

They said that the house
was open for visitors.
l had no idea....

May l see you back
to the village?
No!

l'm very fond of walking.
Yes.

Too bad the subtitles get in the way of the framing. The plant placed 
between them for example , is significant. Nothing in the way this movie is 
so beautifully made has been done by accident and when posting clips this

subliminal, subtle aspects. Watch the whole film taking note of how Wright 
uses windows,for example﻿
comments.author: T Bloopner

comments.text:
This scene shows Lizzy's deep embarrassment at meeting Darcy. She couldn't 
quite look him straight in the face, lowering her head several times. And 
at the end of it all, she heaved a couple of sighs as she hurried away. 
Darcy, here, showed the lack of confidence, after being recently rejected 
by Lizzy. His hand did not show the same confidence as in the carriage 
scene when, after their first touch, his fingers were fully stretched.﻿

comments.author: beffiesue2384

comments.text:
+theNagatuki I love the cinematography the most. The music is astounding. 
The scenes and details are just so so so beautiful. I love the passion in 
here (Darcy stumbling? It may not be 100% true to his book character but I 
like this interpretation). I love the symbolism (the hand? and many scenes 
have sneaky symbols). Joe Wright, director ,made it clear that when 
Elizabeth was in Pemberley,seeing all those sculptures and decorations also 
meant seeing Darcy's style and appreciation of beauty, which also helped 
her in understanding more about his character -- though I do agree that 
this wasn't clear; normal interpretation would be that realizing his wealth 
changed her mind. Regardless, I find it overall very beautiful though I 
acknowledge that characters are more modernised and deviate from the book a 
little, but that's what I enjoy.
comments.author: aurielle

comments.text:
+Ginn Schaefer I've watched that version (*edit:* the 1995 version), and 
it's *terrible*, imo. There's no youthful exuberance in Elizabeth (and how 
can there be, when the cast itself is at least a decade older than they 
should've been?). She's infinitely whiny, and not remotely believable when 
she suddenly turns to "loving" Darcy. There's no chemistry between them, 
and it seems seeing Pemberley changed her mind more than anything else.
It seems to me that, had Colin Firth not been cast, the whole series 
would've been forgotten at this point; the only way it's ever mentioned is 
in conjunction with Firth. (As for Mrs. Bennet, that '95 performance was 
*painful* to listen to, she shrieked every line. Awful.)
To each his own, to be sure. I just think this one (*edit:* the 2005 film) 
is well-researched and captures the spirit of the two *young* lovers quite 
well, making it quite believable.
comments.author: theNagatuki

comments.text:
+Esther Ingram OMG Emma mini series is so good too, it is my favourite 
alongside this. THIS is the ultimate winner ;)
comments.author: aurielle

comments.text:
+Ginn Schaefer I love the novel of course, but absolutely detest the 1995 
mini series. It's so bland and while I agree that it captures the book 
really well, I don't like movies that try to completely reproduce the 
source material. This movie gives me the same kind of feelings that the 
book did, and I consider myself a big Jane Austen fan. I've read all her 
work and have seen all film productions. Still, this movie remains the one 
of the only ones I watch frequently (Northanger Abbey 2007 and the Emma 
mini series being the other two)

comments.text:
Watch the Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle 1995 version, and I promise you you 
will see the story and never ask for a better two leading actors. It is 
better than reading the book; Mr.Collins the empty headed Pastor is 
perfectly played and written.
This movie is just fluff and re-written to sound like a Pretty Woman = 
Harlequin Romance novel set in 1812.  Just like all the other silly 
attempts to write like Jane Austin's character to the writer's image...it 
fails horribly.
                      You are not a true Austen fan until you watch the 
1995 version. 
Only casting mistakes were with Mrs Bennet & Jane Bennet both women were 
suppose to be more attractive than casted.but their acting excuses this 
error.

comments.author: Kenne Adams

comments.text:
In my understanding of the book, Darcy wasn't necessarily proud, other than 
what was due to his position. Darcy was SHY, and his difficulty interacting 
with people he didn't know was wrongly interpreted as arrogance by many 
(especially Elizabeth). There's a lot of evidence in the book for this 
notion, but I particularly like Austen's use of Georgiana for emphasis: 
Georgiana was described as so afraid of offending people that it made her 
extremely hesitant to interact. Darcy was similar. That's why the script 
for this movie described Darcy as "brooding with introversion."

If anything, be mad at the fact that Georgiana was wrongly portrayed in 
this movie.

comments.author: Lana Small

comments.text:
Wonderful scene. Joe Wright said that they intentionally had Georgiana play 
the same score from the beginning of the movie, when Elizabeth enters her 
house, in this scene. They did it to convey that the Darcy estate felt like 
home to Elizabeth, even though it looked different. In a sense, they wanted 
to convey that Darcy and Elizabeth "recognized each other from their 
future."

And now that I think about it, this song was also playing at the end, when 
they get engaged. So we hear it once at Elizabeth's home, hear it again at 
Darcy's, and hear it a last time when the two finally unite.

Sigh... So romantic...﻿

comments.text:
It's really weak comparing to the first movie. It's not authentic... The 
way they behave, the way they talk, even look. It's all from the 20th 
century, not 18th. Her hair in this episode, for example - are you kidding 
me??? Her family didn't have a fortune, but it's not explaining why pigs 
were walking in the garden. Putting together all these details, I just 
don't believe this movie. Actors are decent, but all this stuff is not 
Pride & Prejudice any more, it's totally deprived of its' charms
comments.author: Zoya
